a b s t r a c t
Laser has long been used for material processing, and its applications to nanomaterials for their direct synthesis, positioning and processing are currently active fields of study. The main mechanism of typical laser processes is photothermal reaction by a focused laser that remotely generates confined temperature field at a desired position with high controllability. The laser-induced elevated temperature enables direct synthesis of nanomaterials in both gas and liquid environment as well as photophysical processing of nanomaterials through melting or vaporization, represented by laser sintering and ablation processes, in spatially selective manners. On the other hand, recent advances in laser process further incorporates not only different optical responses such as optical forces and photochemical reactions for more advanced manipulation of nanomaterials, but also the interaction between electromagnetic waves, nanostructures and underlying substrates to facilitate novel processing those cannot be achieved by any other means including laser nanowelding for percolation network and laser thinning for two dimensional nanoma-
aser reduction terials. At the same time, the shortcomings of laser process in nanomaterial processing such as limited resolution and low throughput are tackled through introducing different optical schemes together with the integration with other systems. In this review, we summarize the development and current status of digital selective laser methods for nanomaterials in broad aspects that cover from nanomaterial synthesis to its processing.

Nanomaterials, having ultrasmall sizes with confined dimenions and tailored shapes, show number of interesting properties nd find their applications in diverse areas including various anoscale electronics [1], advanced energy devices [2] and even for iomedical purposes [3], while these nanomaterial based devices re fabricated through two basic steps of synthesis and processing f nanomaterials in principle. The synthesis of nanomaterials, being ither templated or non-templated, is typically conducted in gas r solution environments, and large amount of attention has been evoted to uniform and large scale synthesis while expanding the ange of their sizes and shapes with high controllability [4,5]. The anomaterials synthesized through these conventional procedures re non-site-specific in general. As a result, to make functional anomaterial based devices, as-synthesized nanomaterials has to ndergo additional procedures such as harvesting and relocation o the specific site at the target substrate in order to be applied as final device. Consequently, complex multiple processes including ottom-up approaches represented by self-assembly and topown approaches by photolithography, accompanied by various ost-processing, are broadly employed not only to synthesize, conrol, position and manipulate these nanomaterials for further use, ut also to construct final applications in proof-of-concept standoints [6,7]. These approaches, although studied comprehensively, till possess numerous drawbacks and limitations. Self-assembly nd other bottom-up approaches are not reliable nor appropriate or site-specific purposes in general, providing only overall alignng or ordering of nanomaterials with vague domains. On the other and, photolithography based top-down processes fail in utilizing erits of nanomaterials by bringing harsh processing environents with huge wastes as well as limited throughput, although he detailed shortcomings of each technique are different in their eparate ways.
As an alternative to conventional complex multistep pproaches, laser affords potential solutions to these probems and enable a novel integration of synthesis and processing f nanomaterials in highly selective manners. Laser based process an greatly reduce the process lead time and simplify the nanomaerial based nanofabrication process by removing multiple steps or growth, harvest, manipulation/placement, and integration of anomaterial. Laser has been long used in material processing, nd its known applications are exceptionally diverse with regard o its material selectivity and interaction time [8]. While the eneral advantages of laser in material processing – non-contact, irect writing nature with rapid processing speeds, spatially onfined reaction, 3D compatibility and consistent processing haracteristics – are maintained, additional selectivity can be onveyed in its application to nanomaterials due to the sharply unable parameters of laser light coupled to the unique properties f nanomaterials. As a result, the laser provides not only effective lternative to the conventional multistep processes, but also new elective synthesis method and innovative processing schemes for fficient usage of nanomaterials with minimized environmental equirements and damage on the substrate. This review covers igital selective laser based synthesis, positioning and processing f nanomaterials in broad aspects, while more emphasis is put on pecific nanomaterials such as metal and metal oxide nanopartiles (NPs), nanowires (NWs), carbon based nanomaterials and 2D anosheets.

aser based nanomaterial synthesis and positioning
First step towards the fabrication of nanomaterial based devices s to synthesize the required nanomaterial, while some specific
PRESS xxx (2016) xxx–xxx
applications further involve precise positioning of the synthesized nanomaterial at the designated locations. Based on the local photothermal, photo-chemical or photo-thermo-chemical reaction with a focused irradiation beam, laser enables a site specific growth of nanomaterial for direct synthesis and integration of nanomaterial at the same time. Laser synthesis of nanomaterial can be conducted in either gas or solution environment, depending on the type of precursor material for the target nanomaterial. As a separate issue, the nanomaterial prepared by bulk synthesis and harvest in advance through separate process can be manipulated to the specific location of target substrate by the means of laser processes such as optical tweezing or transfer methods, which also will be briefly introduced. As this review concentrates primarily on the selective laser methods, we will not discuss laser ablation method for non-site-specific purposes [9,10] in laser induced nanomaterial synthesizing techniques.
Selective laser synthesis of nanomaterial in a gas environment
Two basic components in synthesizing nanomaterials are the source material and the elevated temperature to activate the chemical reaction for growth. In a typical nanomaterial growth in a gas environment, the target substrate goes through bulk heating within the tube furnace which contains the precursor gas, and the growth occurs over the entire substrate without any spatial selectivity and subsequent photolithographic method is needed for further patterning. For selective laser synthesis process, bulk heating and subsequent patterning is replaced by the laser-induced local heating and subsequent local chemical reaction. The focused laser beam, incident on a specific point on the target substrate, is absorbed in relation to the optical properties of the substrate, and a localized temperature field is generated at the corresponding spot to induce confined chemical reaction and growth of the nanomaterial whose spatial profile is interrelated to the thermal properties of the laser absorbing layer and the surroundings. Selective laser induced nanomaterial synthesis process shares similar concepts with the previously reported localized heating schemes in many aspects [11], however, primary difference lies in the heat generation mechanism.
Laser interacts with various elementary excitations in the substrate which can be optically active including interband and intraband transitions. The detailed mechanism of laser induced thermal process therefore depends on the type of material and the laser parameters, however, it is known that the laser can be considered as a simple heat source as far as the characteristic time for the initial processing step is significantly higher than the relaxation time and the heating process does not produce any phase changes [8]. Unlike continuous wave that provides constant laser intensity with respect to time, pulsed laser can have various pulse duration and shape which have strong effect on heating characteristics. In general, a single laser pulse yields extremely fast temperature increase followed by rapid cooling after the end of the laser pulse [12]. For multiple pulse irradiation, the temperature swings up and down according to the laser pulses. Meanwhile, the average temperature rise is reliant on the repetition rate. Significant increase in the average temperature is only observable when the repetition rate is high enough so that the surface temperature does not cool to its original value before the next pulse arrives. This trend is well depicted in the study of the laser-written waveguides with femtosecond laser that shows heat accumulation effects according to variable repetition rate [13]. The heat from photothermal process firstly increases the temperature of the surface and dissipates into

The early studies with CNT verified that the proposed laser CVD (LCVD) process enables position-controlled growth of nanomaterial at high precision with small feature size. The LCVD process is readily extended to other nanomaterials, especially for graphene. The interest towards graphene has been ever-growing since its recent Nobel Prize nomination, and the synthesis of graphene sheet on demand has emerged as an important issue accordingly. Synthesis methods for graphene are widely reported in mechanical, chemical and thermal perspectives [21], whereas laser synthesis is mostly related to the thermal means. The selective laser synthesis process can be directly applied to Silicon Carbide (SiC) substrate to induce surface decomposition of Si-rich face to synthesize epitaxial graphene by using either pulsed laser [22] or continuous-wave (CW) laser [23]. With the laser process, not only the thickness of the graphene film could be easily controlled from few layer down to a single monolayer through regulating the laser fluence, but also the resultant graphene film showed several interesting features such as the absence of surface reconstruction [22] that can be found in other thermally grown epitaxial graphene film. Moreover, due to the rapid heating and cooling rates, the stacking order or stacking faults of epitaxial graphene can be influenced, which in turn will affect the carrier mobility [23]. Besides thermal decomposition of SiC, graphene can be prepared through CVD method on metal catalysts including Nickel (Ni) and Copper (Cu) [21]. Through scanning the focused laser beam on Ni foil, graphene layer is continuous synthesized along the scanned path [24] (Fig. 2d). It is noticeable that the growth rate of the laser synthesis is much faster than the conventional thermal CVD method up to several orders of magnitude, which is one of huge advantages of localized growth that has been reported elsewhere [11,25]. The properties of laser synthesized graphene are further investigated through optical color difference as well as G-band and 2D-band ratio of Raman spectrum as in Fig. 2e, showing that a variety types of graphene from monolayer to bi-layer and multi-layer can be achieved in relation to the laser scanning speed [24]. Meanwhile, laser synthesis of graphene has been attempted on other substrates besides metal catalysts film including quartz [26] and Silicon (Si) [27] substrate. A layer of photoresist (PR) is coated on these substrates in advance as carbon atom supplier. As the substrates partially melt due to the laser heating, the carbon atoms are dissolved into the substrate and extracted when the temperature is decreased to form graphene on the surface. These attempts are similar to the synthesis of graphene on metal catalysts, however, the as-produced graphene was typically two to three layers thick [26,27].
Another class of nanomaterial synthesized with selective laser process is functional NWs which also require high temperature in gas environment in typical vapor-liquid-solid (VLS) method. The process is almost identical to other LCVD methods except that different precursor gas and catalyst layer are utilized. One of huge benefits of using laser process is that multi-parametric study, which is often very laborious and energy wasting to be conducted in conventional CVD equipment by a bulk heating furnace, can be readily accomplished by laser process in a single platform as rapid prototyping. By changing the laser power and irradiation time at each spot in programmable manner, the kinetics of laser-assisted Si NW growth was investigated [17] (Fig. 2f). The activation energy was calculated to be smaller than the one reported for the bulk heating in a furnace process at similar conditions, which is presumably originated from the small growth area with three-dimensional gas transport. It was also revealed that the laser irradiation direction

elective laser synthesis of nanomaterial in a liquid environment
Huge drawbacks of synthesizing functional NWs in a gas phase recursor are the high temperature that easily reaches over 1000 ◦C
or their efficient growth, the need for a very expensive vacuum hamber and the usage of highly toxic precursor gases. With the CVD method, entire substrate does not need to undergo such high emperature, however, the growth temperature still hampers the election of applicable substrates. Synthesis of nanomaterial in liqid environments [30] via hydrothermal and polyol methods thus ttracted large amount of attention by providing alternative routes o prepare nanomaterials at a moderate temperature in an eco-

temperature under 100 ◦ C with water based precursor solution [31]. Initially, the laser-assisted patterned growth of ZnO nanostructure in a liquid environment has been attempted by various schemes, such as utilizing laser direct writing to pattern resist layer to prevent the nucleation selectively [32]. For the first direct laser synthesis of ZnO NW, laser induced hydrothermal growth (LIHG) has been proposed, which is essentially identical to LCVD except that the entire process is conducted in a liquid precursor solution [25]. However, laser induced nanomaterial synthesis in liquid need more sophisticated temperature control to prevent liquid boiling. In typical LIHG process, the target sample is immersed in precursor solution, and the laser beam is focused on the surface through the precursor solution to create laser-induced temperature field inside the liquid. Similar to the results of LCVD growth, ZnO NW growth occurs in hemispheric area with LIHG process, resulting in sea-urchin shape upon the complete process as shown in Fig. 3a. Compared to the conventional hydrothermal growth by bulk heating, ZnO NW grown with LIHG process exhibited much faster growth rate which is around an order of magnitude higher. Such peculiarity in the growth rate is in accordance to the other analogous studies [11,24], and this phenomenon in liquid environment is probably due to the natural convention produced by the temperature gradient from confined temperature field and potential superheating at the micron-scale heating together with negligible consumption of ions in precursor reservoir. In LIHG process, the growth rate typically shows asymptotic characteristics over growth time, and the length of the ZnO NW converges to a threshold value. This tendency is primarily due to the limited size of the laserinduced temperature field and the effect of the growing ZnO NWs as thermal fins. As a result, laser power modulation was required during the growth for longer ZnO NW [33] (Fig. 3b and c). LIHG process can be directly applied for the fabrication of ZnO NW based electronics. As a simplest form, ultra-violet (UV) sensor is fabricated with two ZnO NW arrays grown by LIHG which were connected to each other forming photo-sensitive network channels between two electrodes [25,34] (Fig. 3d). Besides, unique feature of these

Having the irradiated rea directly and selectively transferred to the acceptor, laser transer is analogous to other printing techniques, however, free from oncerning the solution rheological properties due to a dry transer nature. hich is a thin laser absorbing layer for the conversion of laser into eat to create vapor pocket that delivers impulse force to the target aterial. In the laser transfer, nanomaterials can be either trans-

but Si nanodroplet initiates from donor substrate itself. Because of ultrafast heating and local melting induced by laser, the molten Si formed a semispherical shape. As the laser pulse energy increases, its center-of-mass acquired upward-directed momentum and elevated to be transferred to the acceptor substrate as schematically illustrated in Fig. 5a. Further control of the pulse energy resulted in droplets with different sizes which in turn showed tailored optical properties (Fig. 5b). Similar studies have been also conducted for laser-induced transfer of metallic nanodroplets as well [57]. Laser transfer is mostly conducted on a donor material prepared at planar thin film layer, however, vertically aligned CNT (VA-CNT) and 2D nanomaterials such as graphene are some of the exceptions. In the case of VA-CNT, as its synthesis is performed in high temperature, laser transfer after its growth is a crucial step to apply VA-CNT to flexible substrates. For the direct transfer of VA-CNT to flexible substrate, the VA-CNT was irradiated with CW laser while the target substrate was mechanically pressed [58]. As the polymer substrate becomes partially viscous due to the laser heating, the tip of VA-CNT is partially soaked with the polymer owing to the capillary force. Subsequent dissipation of heat through highly thermally conductive VA-CNT enabled welding of VA-CNT with the flexible substrate to enable selective transfer (Fig. 5c). The orientation of VA-CNT on the flexible substrate can be further controlled by simple mechanical rolling. Graphene, being atomically continuous and having low ablation threshold, is another nanomaterial that is demanding to apply laser transfer process. As a consequence, an auxiliary PMMA layer was employed to transfer graphene as graphene/PMMA layer [59]. The graphene/PMMA layer was firstly attached to the target substrate through self-flattening which originated from the surface tension, and the boundary of the desired pattern was ablated by a pulsed laser, so that the pattern remained on the target substrate upon detaching the graphene/PMMA template. The resultant graphene/PMMA pattern transferred by laser induced pattern transfer (LIPT) technique exhibited enhanced adhesion to the substrate, presumably due to the PMMA melting at the pattern edge during the ablation procedure. LIPT can be applied to wide range of substrates including very thin flexible substrates and even on a trench structure to fabricate PMMA/graphene cantilever (Fig. 5d). Considering the complexity of building cantilever structure with conventional photolithographic processes, laser transfer has certain advantages in fabrication of MEMS as well. Besides, metal NP film can be utilized as efficient sacrificial layer for the laser transfer as a result of its tunable optical properties and low laser ablation threshold from loosely bonded particles [60]. The reduced thermal conductivity of the NP is also beneficial for the hindrance of thermal damage on the transferred material, making nanomaterial enabled laser transfer (NELT) apposite for heat sensitive materials (Fig. 5e and f). This point has been confirmed by comparing fluorescence spectral intensities before and after transferring heat sensitive OLED material with NELT process, which show negligible change in its characteristics.
Laser based nanomaterial processing
Nanomaterials have been used in various applications in diverse areas, and they often require additional processing after their synthesis and positioning according to their usage. Laser, having high materials selectivity in processing and broad range of parameters, can bring various photo-thermal, photo-chemical and photo-thermo-chemical reactions on nanomaterials depending on the purpose. In this review, research on selective laser sintering
methods for nanomaterials: From synthesis to processing, Nano
and selective laser ablation will be covered as representative additive and subtractive laser processes on nanomaterials. Since these two processes are basically photo-physical, a subsection is assigned to laser induced photo-reduction that involves chemical reaction.

Photophysical subtractive method: selective laser ablation
Contrary to the laser sintering process where laser scanned area turns into conductive electrodes, laser ablation is a representative subtractive method that removes nanomaterials from the laser scanned area selectively. Being a direct writing method, selective laser ablation can be an appropriate substitution of selective laser sintering for the patterns with high areal densities. Moreover, since the nanomaterial deposition techniques are well-established for uniform thin film, selective laser ablation can be utilized as a postprocessing patterning scheme which can be integrated together with other steps developed previously. Although numerous lasermatter interactions and feedback mechanisms are known, laser ablation, similar to the laser sintering, is largely based on photothermal reaction and incorporate a high power pulsed laser instead of CW laser in general to induce dramatic temperature rise for material vaporization. Regarding its applications to nanomaterials, metal NPs were proven to be promising candidates for selective laser ablation due to their enhanced laser absorption, low melting temperature and low thermal conductivity which primarily arise from size effect [87,88]. Compared to their bulk counterparts, the ablation threshold fluences required for these metal NPs are almost an order-of-magnitude lower as a consequence. At the same time, the ablation feature is well-defined for NP film even with nanosecond laser pulses, which are often too long to enable high-resolution surface patterning at good quality, together with reduced amount of ejecta because of the weak bonding between the NPs. It was further confirmed that these features are only originated from the thin film with discrete NPs, as the sintered NP film shows substantial differences in its ablation features as shown in Fig. 8a [88]. Such difference between sintered and unsintered metal NPs can be advantageous in the selective fabrication of multilayered structure, as the damage on the underlying sintered NP during the laser ablation of the upper layer is effectively suppressed [89]. The electronics with multilayered structure such as transistors are fabricated as proof-of-concept through applying the selective pulsed laser ablation by differential ablation threshold (SPLA-DAT) [90].
The limited resolution of the laser ablated feature on NP film can be overcome through the same schemes employed in the selective laser sintering using near-field techniques [74,91]. On the other hand, instead of being ablated, metal NP can be utilized as dynamic local nanoscale heater to induce nano-ablation feature on other material. A single metal NP is manipulated laterally by the optical forces while it is also heated up by the same laser beam as a result of the strong plasmonic absorption in nanomaterials [92], and this optically driven nanoburner enables subdiffraction-limited milling of a polymer film through its thermal decomposition (Fig. 8b). Besides, the residual patterns after the laser ablation can be employed in creating nanopatterns below its diffraction limit via laser beam shaping. A thin film subject to the laser ablation is generally at nanoscale in depth, however, its lateral ablation feature as well as the residual patterns created by a focused laser beam is at microscale [93] unless it is tightly focused through high NA optics. However, by controlling thermocapillary effect induced by the laser through beam shaping, the residual fea-

According to the laser power, the laser reductive sintering process can be divided into several distinctive regimes. The oxide NPs are converted into continuous conductive electrode upon successful application of laser reductive sintering, and repeated application of laser reduction is not as effective as the first since the surface area of NPs are no longer exposed. Recently, the attention has been concentrated on the laser eduction of graphene oxide (GO). Laser reduction of GO into raphene layers occurs through momentum transfer from photons o induce rebinding of atoms within GO, and it is a facile way to preare layered graphene sheets. The conversion of GO into reduced O (rGO) can be observed not only from color change, but also y Raman signal, X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra nd XRD measurement that show loss of oxygen containing groups 108]. A specific application that draw keen attention with the rGO s supercapacitor. By sandwiching and patterning a free-standing ydrated GO film with lasers, supercapacitor with monolithic rGOO-rGO structure is readily fabricated of which hydrated GO is tilized as electrolyte [109]. The GO exhibits anisotropic ionic conuctivity because of its lamella structure, and its capacitance can e highly enhanced by adding external electrolytes. The stacked GO heets can be turned into well exfoliated few layered laser-scribed raphene (LSG) film even with low-power infrared laser from comercial DVD optical drive [110,111] (Fig. 9e). The LSG film, having igh electrical conductivity as well as large specific surface area, is irectly applied as the electrode of electrochemical capacitors that xhibits ultrahigh energy density even without any binders or curent collectors as in Fig. 9f. The laser rGO finds its application in ther areas as well such as microcircuits [108] and optical lenses 112].
ther selective laser induced reactions on nanomaterials
Having a sharply defined parameters together with wide range f tunability, laser can induced other various reactions in a highly elective and confined manner. In this section, recent laser proesses for nanomaterials are briefly introduced. While these laser nduced reactions cannot be categorized clearly, some of the topcs including laser annealing, welding, thinning and reshaping are ased on photo-thermal reaction that mainly involves physical hanges. Aside from sintering and ablation, laser can induce simple eating to enable local annealing of the nanomaterial to the elecrical contacts with minimum thermal damage. It is shown that he laser annealing on Molybdenum disulfide (MoS2) and metal educes the contact resistance to lower the Schottky barrier width nd results in a significant improvement in the performance of the ransistor on a heat-sensitive flexible substrate [113]. The size of he photo-thermal annealing can be reduced by tightly focusing he laser beam, however, highly selective annealing is feasible even ithout ultrasmall laser spot for some specific metallic nanostrucures owing to the localized field enhancement from plasmonic ffect. This unique feature of laser heating has been proven to e particularly beneficial for the thermal treatment of metal NW ercolation network, which is regularly required to reduce the ontact resistance at the NW junction. Upon the laser irradiation, ubstantial heating only occurs at the NW junction and enables ano-welding of discrete NWs due to the high field enhancement t the NW junction point [114,115]. Together with rapid scanning peed, the thermal treatment of NW percolation network can be onducted with minimized thermal damage and ultrashort local eating time, and this novel process is confirmed to be suitable for he thermal annealing of specific NWs that easily oxide in ambient ondition [115] (Fig. 10a). The laser ablation process in the previous
Please cite this article in press as: S. Hong, et al., Digital selective laser Today (2016), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.nantod.2016.08.007
ection only covers total removal of the target nanomaterial, howver, by controlling the laser parameters and exploiting the role f the substrate as a heat sink, monolayer 2D nanosheets can be btained through the laser thinning process [116,117] (Fig. 10b).
PRESS xxx (2016) xxx–xxx 15
The resultant 2D nanosheet exhibits the physical properties similar to that of pristine exfoliated single layer. Pulsed laser also can induce rapid melting and cooling that results in the nanomaterials with different morphology. As an example, the tips of hydrothermally grown ZnO NWs are tailored into spherical shapes by irradiating a short laser pulse [118] (Fig. 10c). Closer examination revealed that the spherical tip is actually a hollow shell that can serve as templates to grow very sharp tips through secondary growth. Besides material processing, highly controllable localized heat source is also a useful tool for characterization, for instance, to investigate the photothermoelectric effect of nanomaterials [119].
Together with laser thinning, site-selective laser processes that involves chemical change are being actively developed for fine tuning of nanomaterials, especially for 2D thin nanomaterials recently. For graphene, air-stable n-doping is successfully achieved through photoinduced oxidation of 6,13-bis(triisopropylsilylethynyl) pentacene (TIPS-pentacene) coated on top of the graphene [120]. The effect of n-doping is confirmed from resistance vs gate voltage curves and Raman G-band frequency image. Likewise, laser doping of 2D transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs) such as MoS2 and Tungsten diselenide (WSe2) is conducted inside a precursor gas environment, where the role of laser is to create chalcogen vacancies in the TMDC and dissociate the dopant molecules [121] (Fig. 10d and e). On the contrary, laser can be used to eliminate the chalcogen vacancies as well to achieve atomic healing of TMDC. It is shown that the conductivity of monolayer WSe2 can be greatly enhanced through passivating these vacancies with the oxygen from air through focused laser annealing [122]. Selective laser selenization of Tungsten trioxide (WO3) film is an example of more active transformation of the nanomaterial [123]. The amorphous WO3 film is converted into few-layers WSe2 by locally heating the WO3 film in the presence of selenium vapor. Besides TMDCs, laser conversion has been also applied to polymer substrates to achieve its carbonization at ambient condition [124] or obtain porous graphene films by converting sp3-carbon atoms to sp2-carbon atoms [125].
In addition, it is worth mentioning that the laser, though not directly applied to nanomaterial directly, is a versatile tool in nanopatterning as well. Periodic nanopatterns have been regularly fabricated with laser interference lithography in both 2D and 3D with numerous beam configurations [126], and two photon polymerization is the most viable candidate for the fabrication of an arbitrary 3D structures at nanoscale, which is still under active exploration to improve the processing accuracy further [127]. The resolution of these techniques remains at several hundred nanometers in general, however, recent studies on laser nanopatterning with block copolymer (BCP) via transient laser heating open a new prospect in the nanopatterning, enabling patterning resolution of several tens of nanometers with better controllability [128,129] (Fig. 10f and g)
Perspective
Laser has been explored as a versatile digital selective tool in synthesizing, positioning and processing various nanomaterials at site-specific manners, and the process of development as well as current status of these laser based methods have been broadly discussed in this review. For the nanomaterial synthesis, laser has been utilized as a localized heat source for selective photo-thermal or photo-thermo-chemical reaction to enable direct digital selective synthesis of nanomaterials at an arbitrary point even on 3D structures. The laser based nanomaterial synthesis is fast, and appli-

Prof. Sukjoon Hong is currently an assistant professor in Mechanical Engineering department at Hanyang University in South Korea. He received B.S. and M.S. degree from Department of physics at Seoul National University and Ph.D. degree in Mechanical Engineering from KAIST (Korea) in 2014, followed by post-doc at UC Berkeley. His research has been concentrated on various laser processes for nanomaterials and its application to flexible/stretchable devices. He has published over 30 papers in peer reviewed journals including Advanced Materials, ACS Nano, Nano Letters, etc.
Mr. Habeom Lee graduated from Yonsei University in 2011 and received his M.S. degree in Mechanical Engineering from KAIST in 2013. He is currently a Ph.D. candidate in Mechanical Engineering, Seoul National University from Republic of Korea. He has published over 10 papers in international journals including Advanced Materials, ACS Applied Materials and Interfaces and Journal of Material Chemistry A.
Prof. Junyeob Yeo is currently an assistant professor in Department of Physics at Kyungpook National University, Republic of Korea. He specializes in optics and thermodynamics based process development for flexible electronics via study of light-matter interaction. He received B.S. and M.S. degree from Department of physics at Seoul National University and a Ph. D. from Department of Mechanical Engineering at KAIST in 2013. After then, he worked as a postdoctoral researcher in Department of Mechanical Engineering at UC Berkeley in 2014-15.
Prof. Seung Hwan Ko is currently a professor in mechanical engineering department in Seoul National University, Korea. He received B.S. in Yonsei University (2000), M.S. in Seoul National University (2002), Ph.D degree in mechanical engineering at UC Berkeley in 2006. Before joining Seoul National University, he worked as a post-doctoral researcher at UC Berkeley (2006–2009) and an associate professor at KAIST (2009–2013). His research interest is
methods for nanomaterials: From synthesis to processing, Nano
process development for flexible, stretchable and wearable electronics, and crack assisted nanomanufacturing. He published over 100 peer reviewed journal papers.

metadata.abstractText: Laser has long been used for material processing, and its applications to nanomaterials for their direct synthesis, positioning and processing are currently active fields of study. The main mechanism of typical laser processes is photothermal reaction by a focused laser that remotely generates confined temperature field at a desired position with high controllability. The laser-induced elevated temperature enables direct synthesis of nanomaterials in both gas and liquid environment as well as photophysical processing of nanomaterials through melting or vaporization, represented by laser sintering and ablation processes, in spatially selective manners. On the other hand, recent advances in laser process further incorporates not only different optical responses such as optical forces and photochemical reactions for more advanced manipulation of nanomaterials, but also the interaction between electromagnetic waves, nanostructures and underlying substrates to facilitate novel processing those cannot be achieved by any other means including laser nanowelding for percolation network and laser thinning for two dimensional nanomaaser reduction terials. At the same time, the shortcomings of laser process in nanomaterial processing such as limited resolution and low throughput are tackled through introducing different optical schemes together with the integration with other systems. In this review, we summarize the development and current status of digital selective laser methods for nanomaterials in broad aspects that cover from nanomaterial synthesis
